posts.name: brian smith
posts.cooked:
Hi all,

We’re using a CANdle to drive a 16x16 addressable LED array. The CANdle library has a basic setColor() that takes a starting LED and number of LEDs to set to a given RGB(w) value. Right now we just use the array for basic status to the driver, so all LEDs are the same color based on whatever status we want to display.

I’d like to do much more with the display. Ideally, I’d really like to pass a 256-entry array of on/off values (all of which can be the same color). There’s a slightly more advanced setColor() that takes a start and length and will set those LEDs to the given color. However, worse case, I would still have to call that 256 times if every other LED were on for example.

I’d like to avoid having to call setColor() in a loop. Is there anything better than doing that that I missed?

Thanks

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
While LEDs might be a bit lower on their priority list, my standard response for any issues or technical question with a CTRE product is “Have you tried reaching out to CTRE support for help on this?”

Their support is extremely helpful with technical questions like this (especially when you’re trying to do something that might not be well documented yet), our programming team has spent countless (productive) hours on the phone with them over the last few years and they’ve always been great to work with!

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
WPILib has some new classes for addressable LEDs and I see them now in github. I’ve used them and they work great.

Other teams have written pattern makers. I’ve seen them referenced in CD threads. There are other resources as addressable is commonly used. There are some references that show the patterns for letters and numbers.

Last season my team used these CTRE imports to do a lot of patterns:

posts.name: brian smith
posts.cooked:
Can you use those WPIlib classes with a CANdle though? I was thinking they were via PWM on the RIO?

I’m trying to display a team logo or spell messages on the LED display. I have a bunch of old routines I wrote that essentially create an array of on/off values to do that. It would be really nice if I could just call setRGB(r,g,b, array , array .length) essentially.

Thanks

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Yes, you can wire the Rio’s addressable LED output from the PWM port on the Rio to the CANH/CANL signals of the CANdle, and the CANdle will pass through the signal (effectively mostly just providing power); see section 2.6 of the CANdle user’s guide.  Then you can use the buffer set options of AddressableLED which sounds like exactly what you want.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
There is a separation between generating patterns in a buffer and actually sending that buffer out the PWM port. You want to send your patterns out the CANdle port but somehow patterns are still generated by your programming.

I haven’t tied the two together so I don’t know the details but we’ve used both methods of driving the patterns to the LEDs.

You may be wanting a simple way to magically turn LEDs on/off. No - they are independent LEDs but you (or someone does) write methods to handle the repetitive looping. For example there is unlikely a method readily available to light every other LED so write one yourself. It’s fairly straight forward and you’ve already done something like it. Make all the lights black - usually with one statement. Loop through the buffer 0 to 255 incrementing by 2 and setting the color. Make the method more general purpose by accepting an increment amount.

If you are doing animation that isn’t performed in the LED driver then the colors do have to be refreshed every cycle. Not sure but I’d bet the CANdle is not doing the animation but the CTRE roboRIO library is.

posts.name: brian smith
posts.cooked:
Ahhh, I missed that. Yeah, this should work well enough.

Thanks!
